Award.AwardTitle: The collective behavior of deep fault asperities during non-volcanic tremor and slow slip
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores a recently discovered geophysical phenomenon, non-volcanic tremor, whose physical origins are not yet known. This multi-component project combines theory, observations and experiments in a synergistic way, and gathers a team with expertise in several areas: observational seismology, computational modeling and experimental fracture mechanics. The project will provide new observations, employing data from two distinct regions and from laboratory experiments. Whereas the related phenomenon of episodic slow slip transients has been previously addressed by models and experiments, analog and computational modeling of non-volcanic tremor is only incipient. The proposed research aims at filling that gap while contributing with innovative methodologies in large dataset analysis, multi-scale computational modelling and combined optical and acoustic techniques for imaging fracture. The proposed studies concern regions of the United States and South America that are highly exposed to earthquake hazard. Understanding the relations between non-vocanic remor and mechanics of seismogenic zones, a question addressed by this proposal, can provide important input for earthquake hazard assessment. If NVT activity proves to be a natural creepmeter it will provide a means to remotely monitor the small aseismic slip transients related to the nucleation of large earthquakes. The project will provide new targets for field experiments to study NVT. It will enhance and diversify the expertise of two post-doctoral fellows and will provide training for a graduate student.

This project consists of three components: (1) an observational component proposing a systematic search for NVT in seismic waveform datasets from Southern California and from the Peru-Chile subduction zone; (2) a theoretical and computational component involving the development of a multi-scale modelling approach and studies of the collective behavior of asperities during tremor and slow slip in rate- and- state models and their response to transient and periodic stresses; and (3) an experimental component that will address the effect of transient and periodic loads on the response of fault asperities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tectonic faults can host a diversity of slip behavior, including rapid slip during earthquakes and episodic slow slip accompanied by tiny tremors. Seismological observations have recently revealed complicated patterns of tremor migration that may carry valuable information about the roots of active faults, the incubation environment of large earthquakes. However, these tremor patterns remain unexplained. The goal of this project was to advance our understanding of the mechanics of tremors and slow slip by developing and integrating observational, computational and laboratory studies.

A search for tectonic tremors in southern California led to the identification of high-frequency seismic noise induced by heavy vehicle traffic. This provided higher bounds on the amplitude of tremors in this region and a novel approach to estimate shallow wave attenuation properties. Spontaneous tectonic tremor activity in the 2-8 Hz band was not detected in the San Jacinto fault near Anza: it is either inexistent or weaker than tremor in the central San Andreas fault. Methods were developed to infer the aseismic slip component of small earthquakes from strainmeter data, to detect precursory tremor activity before earthquakes and to infer the evolution of aseismic slip transients from seismicity and geodetic data jointly. No evidence for systematic tremor-like precursory phenomena was found in earthquakes in southern California.

Theoretical models were developed to determine quantitative relations between fault friction properties and tremor patterns (migration speeds and sensitivity to tides). The conceptual model comprises a fault that mostly creeps silently and hosts a collection of sticky spots or asperities that can slide rapidly. Tremor swarms are the result of multiple asperity failures. The model provides relations between tremor migration speeds and the underlying slow slip velocity. The density and strength of the asperities tunes the model between two end-members: weakly-interacting asperities driven by slow slip, and strongly-interacting asperities driving slow slip. The effect of tidal loading on the modulation of tremor activity was also quantified. Tides can have an indirect effect on tremors: tides can modulate slow slip, which in turn modulates tremor activity. The sensitivity depends on the tidal period, on frictional parameters and on the background sliding speed. The modeling framework developed here is also relevant for the study of foreshock sequences driven or accompanied by aseismic slip.

Laboratory experiments in analog materials (gels, plexiglass) were developed that contained the key ingredients of the theoretical model: a heterogeneous fault containing a mixture of stable and unstable patches. Optical and acoustic monitoring allowed a characterization of the seismic and aseismic components of the deformation, which were then compared to models. 

This project provided an early career investigator with opportunities to do integrative research that spans three distinct perspectives on a geophysical problem (observational seismology, theory/simulation, and laboratory experimentation), training and research experience for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Research results were integrated in graduate teaching. The project promoted international collaboration.
